newsitem.title: INDIA: INTERVIEW - UBS to launch $350 mln Indian bond fund.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - UBS to launch $350 mln Indian bond fund.

text.p: Union Bank of Switzerland plans to launch India's largest debt fund by a registered foreign institutional investor, a senior bank official said.
UBS said its $350 million debt fund -- which underlined its growing commitment to Asia -- had been approved by the country's regulators and would be launched shortly.
"In three weeks we would like to start bringing the money in. We have already identified one or two borrowers," Ho-Kee Lim, chairman of UBS in East Asia, told Reuters in an interview.
Lim, who was in Bombay on Sunday, said UBS also planned to launch an equity fund but declined to give any further details.
"The board of UBS has committed itself openly to East Asia -- Europe is our home base, we want to make Asia our second home base," Lim said.
Lim, who was in town for the formal launch of UBS's broking business, said the bank planned to upgrade its offices in China and Bangkok.

The Singapore-based banker said he was unfazed by the ongoing political turmoil following the resignation of Indian Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda after his government lost a confidence vote in parliament on Friday.
"We are not fair weather friends. We're a shy, low profile organisation but we have done some major deals here," Lim said.

UBS has helped finance an $800 million cellular phone project by Indian business group the Birlas and U.S. firm AT&T Corp. The bank is financial adviser to a $1.6 billion power project by U.S. firm Cogentrix.
"Our biggest exposures in Asia are Australia and Korea, where we have about a similar investment, followed by India," Lim said, adding that UBS's India exposure was around $1.0 billion.
Lim said his stockmarket picks for the 1997 calendar year were Thailand, Korea and India.
"I like Thailand and Korea because they have been beaten up quite badly and India because I don't think too many people understand it yet," he said.
He said foreign investors in India were always ready to run when events like a change in government occurred and that resulted in the easy availability of undervalued stocks.
Lim said he favoured a managed depreciation of the Indian rupee as the country moved towards free convertibility.
The government has asked the central bank to set up a panel to prepare a "road map" for making the rupee fully convertible on the capital account.
"It's actually cheaper and more efficient for any currency to depreciate gradually because of interest rate differentials rather than having a massive shock now and then," Lim said.

"Indonesia does it very well. They let the currency depreciate two to three percent a year. It's more orderly, it gives the importers time to adjust and as a result foreign investors ask for less of a premium," he said.
In the last six months, the rupee has appreciated against the dollar on the back of large foreign capital inflows and reduced imports.
The Reserve Bank of India has sought a gradual depreciation of the local currency by stepping up its dollar purchase price.
"If you give the system a shock of 20 percent every now and then, the timing of which is not clear, then overseas investors and foreign exchange traders will ask for a bigger premium."
Lim declined to comment on the investor impact of a recent reversal in aviation policy barring foreign airlines from taking stakes in the domestic sector.
A direct casualty of the new rule is a $600 million joint venture of Singapore Airlines and the country's largest business group, Tata Industries.

"You are in the process of deregulation, of becoming more open. There will be people who will fight you, who will have rearguard action," he said. "I can't speak for Singapore investors but you have got to be very optimistic about India in the long run."
